definition:
at all times : invariably                                      
             
             always smiling

forever                                      
             
             will love you always

at any rate : in any event                                      
             
             You can always try again if it doesn't work this time.
at all times : on every occasion : in a way that does not change
at all times in the past
forever into the future

at all times                                      
             
             My dad always knows the answer.

throughout all time : forever                                      
             
             I'll remember it always.

often, frequently, or repeatedly                                      
             
             People always forget my name.
in: always smiling
will love you always
You can always try again if it doesn't work this time.
He always tries, but he doesn't always succeed.
It's always a pleasure to see you.
I can always tell when he's upset.
This area is always filled with tourists.
Things won't always go as planned.
You're always welcome to stay with us.
He has always been a good friend to me.
Life won't always be this easy.
I always thought they'd get married some day, but they never did.
Isn't that what you've always wanted?
My dad always knows the answer.
I'll remember it always.
People always forget my name.

definition: on every occasion
all the time
for all time in the past
for all time in the future
used for saying that something happens often, especially when this annoys you
in: I always get the eight o’clock train.
My mother and I do not always agree.
Starting a new job is always a bit of a shock.
Is he always this silly?
There’s always a pen in my handbag.
I’ve always liked Sarah.
Has your grandmother always lived with you?
I will always think of you when I hear this song.
There will always be a demand for English teachers.
He’s always forgetting my name.
People from work were always ringing her up at home.
as always
I/you/they etc could always
it/this was always going to be...
there’s always

definition: every time or all the time:
for ever:
at all times in the past:
used with "can" or "could" to suggest another possibility:
again and again, usually in an annoying way:
every time, all the time, or forever:
Always is sometimes used after can or could to suggest another possibility:
in: It's always cold in this room.
She always spells my name wrong.
I'll always remember you.
I've always liked him.
I always thought I'd have children eventually.
If you miss this train you can always catch the next one.
You're always complaining.
He always enjoyed having dinner with friends.
You always try to do your best.
I’ll always remember her.
She’s always (= very often) late.
If you don’t like what’s on TV, you can always change the channel.
Paradigmbreaking discoveries have always been subject to years of scepticism.
There is always the risk, however much the notion of choice is objectified, that an element of subjectivity remains.
In a nutshell, the state will always react as state to the challenges of globalisation, including the challenge from non-state communities and their laws.
Although the affix is basically a prefix, it is not always left-aligned.
There are always 12 current return posts, but different nozzles have different bolt circle diameters for the posts.
Attitudes toward the latter are not always positive.
Although rural speech is stigmatized, it is not obvious that people who always live in a rural environment ever wish to speak like urbanites.
Accordingly, the book's claims are not always supported by strong evidence.
As is well-known, mental states do not always behave this way.
Still, final say always lies with the law-making legislature.
When we see precedents as examples, we are free to note that scopes are not always specifiable in advance.
In most cases, but not always, the eldest son seems to have been the preferred heir.
I have always used these terms interchangeably. 16.
Improvements made on the land or buildings always reverted to the mill without any compensation to the colono, regardless of who had paid for them.
As a rational agent, of course, one always has a reason to act on the strength of some reason.

translated_as@fr: Ils arrivent toujours ici en retard.
Elle n’arrête pas de se plaindre.

definition: I word that was given true meaning by JK Rowling in the legendary book Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.

Marginalized Orientations, Gender identities, And Intersex. it’s meant to be an all inclusive umbrella term for asexuals, homosexuals, multisexuals, trans people, and intersex people. Alternative to LGBTQIAP+
Alternative to MOGII, easier to pronounce.
Always: for a week (or less)-Clearance Herron

Implying huge emotional value.
This word is forever changed because of Harry Potter and The Hunger Games.

A powerful and useful word. A word that can potentially be wrong, but not all the time.

A word that can easily confuse people because how it's defined.

a.)A vague and sarcastic response used to neutralize any statement that can be interpreted as sarcastically-attacking or passive aggressive regarding either you or what you represent.  

b.)A useful response to questions or statements when the answer is yes or no.  It works two-fold as an enhanced replacement for yes or an incredibly sarcastic replacement for no.

c.)A great way to take a compliment
1. How long I want to be with you, make believe with you and live in harmony harmony oh love.2. Song by Erasure
